questions.text: Which of the following drugs acts by causing irreversible inhibition of the initiation complex through binding of the 30S ribosomal subunit?
questions.solution:
Aminoglycosides like gentamicin act by causing irreversible inhibition of the initiation complex through binding of the 30S ribosomal subunit. They cause misreading and premature termination of mRNA translation. 

Aminoglycosides include streptomycin, gentamicin, tobramycin, amikacin, and kanamycin. They are bactericidal and the killing is concentration-dependent.

They are used in the treatment of aerobic gram-negative bacterial infections such as urinary tract infections, mycobacterial infections, tularemia, respiratory infections in cystic fibrosis, and other pseudomonal infections. Anaerobic bacteria are intrinsically resistant to aminoglycosides because the transport of aminoglycosides across the cytoplasmic membrane requires oxygen.  

The adverse effects of aminoglycosides include-

  • Ototoxicity is characterized by irreversible high-frequency hearing loss and vestibular dysfunction. Streptomycin and gentamicin are the most vestibulotoxic. Amikacin, kanamycin, and neomycin mainly affect auditory functions. 
  • Nephrotoxicity due to damage to proximal tubular cells. Neomycin is the most nephrotoxic. Streptomycin is the least nephrotoxic.
  • Acute neuromuscular blockade and apnea. Neuromuscular blockade may be reversed by intravenous administration of a Ca2+ salt. 

Other options

Options A and B- Chloramphenicol and clindamycin act by binding to the 50S subunit of the ribosome.

Option D- Vancomycin is a glycopeptide that inhibits cell wall synthesis. It binds to terminal dipeptide D-Ala-D-Ala of peptidoglycan to inhibit cell wall synthesis.

Related Pearl: Protein synthesis inhibitors: Primary subunit of ribosome binding

Mnemonic: 50 CELLS arranged into 30 TEAM

50s subunit binding:

  • C: Chloramphenicol, Clindamycin
  • E: Erythromycin (macrolides)
  • L: Lincosamides
  • L: Linezolid
  • S: Streptogramins

30s subunit binding

  • Te: Tetracyclines
  • Am: Aminoglycosides

questions.text:
Which of the following measures will you take for effective control of Hepatitis A disease outbreak?

1-Disinfect the water source of the area with adequate chlorination and advice usage of boiled water for consumption

2-Supply condoms to the affected area via a public dispensary for control of the outbreak

3-Isolate the patients and their family till the end of 2 incubation periods 

4-Circulate precautionary orders to the hospital staff as they are at higher risk of this disease due to needle stick injuries
questions.solution:
The given scenario of Hepatitis A outbreak is a type of common source multiple exposure epidemic. It can be controlled by identification of the source(water body/supply/restaurant), confirm contamination, suggest disinfection of water with adequate chlorination, and usage of boiled water for consumption in the meanwhile. 

 

Hepatitis A

Modes of transmission

  • Fecal-oral route: This is the major route of transmission. It can occur directly (handshake after toilet) or indirectly via contaminated food, water, or milk.
  • Parenteral route: This is very rare and occurs during the viral dissemination phase. It occurs during the prodromal phase and not when patients are symptomatic and admitted to the hospital. As a result, healthcare workers are not at increased risk.
  • Sexual transmission may occur in individuals practicing oro-anal methods (usually homosexual men). It however would not cause an outbreak.

Incubation period:

  • 10 to 50 days (usually 14-28 days). Isolation is not an effective measure to control outbreaks as the shedding of the virus is maximum during the early stages of illness when clinical illness may not have started and many patients are asymptomatic yet continue to shed the virus.

Clinical spectrum:

  • The onset of jaundice is preceded by gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, anorexia, and mild fever.
  • Jaundice may appear within a few days of the prodromal period, but anicteric hepatitis is more common.
  • Hepatitis A resolves completely in 98 percent of cases but relapse of symptoms are noted in 3-20 percent of cases

Diagnosis:

  • Laboratory diagnosis of hepatitis A can be obtained by
    • Demonstration of HAV particles or specific viral antigens in the feces, bile, and blood.
    • Anti-HAV appears in the lgM fraction during the acute phase, peaking about 2 weeks after the elevation of liver enzymes. ELISA is the method of choice for measuring HAV antibodies.

Prevention and containment:

  • Control of reservoir: Use of 0.5 percent sodium hypochlorite has been strongly recommended as an effective disinfectant
  • Control of transmission: personal and community hygiene. Hand hygiene before food and after the toilet is highly recommended.
  • 1 mg/L of free residual chlorine can cause the destruction of the virus in 30 minutes at pH values of 8.5 or less. Hence adequate chlorination can be helpful.
  • Patients with chronic liver disease are at increased risk for fulminant hepatitis A and should be vaccinated. Use of hepatitis A vaccine should be considered for pre-exposure(for travelers) and post-exposure(close contacts of affected individuals)prophylaxis.

Vaccines:

  • Two types of hepatitis A vaccines are currently used
    • Formaldehyde-inactivated vaccines
    • Live attenuated vaccines
  • The complete vaccination schedule consists of 2 dose administration into the deltoid muscle. The interval between the first (primary) dose and second (booster) dose is commonly 6-12 months.
  • Following 2 doses of vaccine, the protective efficacy is about 94 percent.

questions.text: A 52-year-old diabetic male patient was found to have a bilateral loss of peripheral visual fields. On tonometry, intraocular pressure was raised. Fundoscopy showed cupping and pallor of the optic disc. Iridocorneal angle was normal on gonioscopy. He is started on a topical drug that reduces the intraocular pressure by increasing the uveoscleral flow. Identify the drug.
questions.solution:
The topical drug started that reduces intraocular pressure by increasing the uveoscleral flow is latanoprost, a prostaglandin analog. It is used in the treatment of open-angle glaucoma. 

This patient's findings of peripheral vision loss, increased intraocular pressure (IOP) with optic disc cupping, and a normal iridocorneal angle is suggestive of open-angle glaucoma.

Topical prostaglandins like latanoprost, travoprost, bimatoprost, and tafluprost are now used as first-line agents to lower IOP. The major mechanism of action is by enhancing the uveoscleral outflow though they also increase trabecular outflow.

The most common ocular side effects are conjunctival hyperemia, eyelash thickening, iris hyperpigmentation, and loss of periorbital fat. These drugs are administered once every day at bedtime and are used with caution in inflamed eyes.

The systemic side effects are uncommon and include occasional headaches, malaise, myalgia, skin rash, and mild upper respiratory infections. Latanoprost is preferred as the first-line due to fewer ocular side effects.

Other options:

Option A: Dorzolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. It reduces IOP by decreasing aqueous production. 

Option C: Mannitol is an osmotic agent, which lowers IOP by creating an osmotic gradient so that water is pulled from the vitreous into the blood vessels. It is used as a short-term treatment to reduce IOP in acute angle-closure glaucoma or prior to intraocular surgery.

Option D: Pilocarpine is a miotic that acts as a cholinergic agonist. In angle-closure glaucoma, cholinergic agents open the angle by contraction of the sphincter pupillae, pulling the iris away from the trabecula.

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost
  • Rho-kinase inhibitor (Netarsudil)

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide)
  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presented with low-grade fever, easy fatiguability, and pain in the right hypochondrium.  A contrast-enhanced CT scan is given below. Which of the following is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and contrast-enhanced CT showing non-enhancing lesions in the liver are suggestive of liver metastasis. Colorectal carcinoma is the most common cause of metastatic lesions in the liver.

The most common site of distant metastasis of colorectal cancer is the liver. These metastases arise from hematogenous spread via the portal venous system. The lung is the next most common site for metastasis.

Metastatic malignancy of the liver is more common than primary hepatic neoplasia. The most common primary sources are the colon, breast, lung, and pancreas. However, primary malignancy from any organ may spread to the liver.

On CT, most metastases are low attenuation on unenhanced images and portal phase images. Features of metastatic lesions:

  • Multiple
  • Variable size
  • Growth in serial imaging

In most cases, multiple nodular metastases may be seen, causing hepatomegaly. The liver weight can exceed several kilograms. In some cases, a solitary metastatic nodule may be present, which can be surgically resected. Massive destruction of hepatocytes or direct obstruction of major bile ducts may cause jaundice.

Resection with a negative surgical margin of 1 cm (R0) has always been considered the gold standard but with chemotherapy, patients with R1 (microscopically negative) resection have similar survival to those with R0 resections.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in red arrow:
questions.solution:
The marked structure can be identified as the superior mesenteric artery, as it lies anterior and superior to the left renal vein.

The superior mesenteric artery originates from the abdominal aorta at the level of the L1 vertebra.

Its branches include:

  • Jejunal branches
  • Ileal branches
  • Middle colic artery
  • Right colic artery
  • Ileocolic artery
  • Inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery

Clinical note: Nutcracker syndrome:

  • The compression of the left renal vein between the abdominal aorta and the superior mesenteric artery, appears in the sagittal plane, as if a nutcracker is crushing a nut (left renal vein).
  • This condition is called nutcracker (left renal vein entrapment) syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the treatment of alcohol abuse causes reduced craving by blocking the opioid receptor?
questions.solution:
Naltrexone causes reduced reward response to drinking and reduced craving by blocking the opioid receptor.

Before prescribing: Evaluate for possible current opioid use; consider a urine toxicology screen for opioids, including synthetic opioids. Obtain liver function tests and follow up periodically.

Acamprosate, naltrexone, and disulfiram are used in the treatment of alcohol dependence.

Other options:

Option A: Chlordiazepoxide is a benzodiazepine used in the treatment of alcohol withdrawal.

Option B: Acamprosate affects glutamate and GABA neurotransmitter systems, but its alcohol-related action is unclear.

Option D: Disulfiram inhibits the intermediate metabolism of alcohol which causes a build-up of acetaldehyde and a reaction of flushing, sweating, nausea, and tachycardia if a patient drinks alcohol.

questions.text: A 72-year old man presented with complaints of reduced vision in the right eye. Kinetic perimetry revealed right homonymous hemianopia. What is the most likely location of the defect in the optic pathway?
questions.solution:
The most likely defect in this patient presenting with right homonymous hemianopia is in the left optic tract. Homonymous hemianopia involves a loss of vision on the same side of the visual field in both eyes.

Other options:

Option A - A lesion affecting the optic chiasma produces heteronymous hemianopia. It involves loss of vision on the opposite sides of visual fields in both eyes. 

Options C and D - Lesions of the retina and optic nerve affect the visual field of only that eye. The visual field of the opposite eye is normal. 

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man comes to see you in your clinic. His wife noticed an area of circular hair loss over the back of his head. There is no other significant past medical history. On examination, there is a 2 cm area of complete, smooth, and circular hair loss with distinct margins. There is no scaling or inflammation present in and around the area of hair loss. Which among the given options is the best treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of alopecia areata. In this patient, with limited patchy hair loss, the treatment of choice is intralesional corticosteroids.

Clinically, it is characterized by discrete, smooth, and circular areas of hair loss. It develops over weeks to months and most patients will see regrowth of hair in the affected region over time. However, recurrence is common. Alopecia areata can affect any part of the body. In rare cases, it may extend to involve the entire scalp (called alopecia totalis) or loss of all hair on the body (called alopecia universalis). The pathology is most likely autoimmune suggested by the infiltration of activated T-cells in and around the hair-bulbs. Features of alopecia areata include-

  • No scaling or inflammation in the area of hair loss.
  • Sparing of white hair
  • Exclamation mark hair are often seen at the margins of the bald patches during active phases of the disease
  • Preservation of hair follicles in the affected area and the follicular orifices may appear as yellow dots on dermoscopy
  • Nail changes associated ranging from roughening of the nail plate to a more well-defined fine stippled pitting.

Treatment for alopecia areata depends on the extent of the disease-

  • Local patchy involvement-
    • Intralesional corticosteroids (Triamcinolone) are the preferred treatment for limited patchy alopecia areata. After treatment, new hair growth is typically seen in six to eight weeks. Treatment can be repeated every four to six weeks until regrowth is achieved.
    • Topical high potency corticosteroids with clobetasol.
    • Second-line drugs for the localized disease include topical agents such as anthralin and minoxidil.
  • Extensive involvement-
    • Contact/topical immunotherapy with agents such as dinitrochlorobenzene (DNCB), diphenylcyclopropenone (DPCP). They are potent contact allergens that have an immunomodulatory role. 
    • Systemic corticosteroids may be used for a short bout to slow hair loss in patients with severe rapidly progressing, extensive hair loss. It is not preferred for long-term treatment as the risks of systemic corticosteroids outweigh the benefits.

 Localized alopecia areata in a patient-

 

 

Other options-

Option A- Topical antifungals are used in tinea corporis.

Option C- Although oral corticosteroids may be used in severe and extensive alopecia areata, it is a long-term recurring disorder and the risks of using a systemic corticosteroid outweigh the benefits, and it is hence not the treatment of choice. 

Option D- Oral tacrolimus is ineffective in treating alopecia areata and hence not used.

questions.text:
During a central line insertion, the patient suffers a pleural puncture and develops breathing difficulty and sharp pain. There is an absence of breath sounds on the right side. A chest X-ray is done and appears as shown below. A needle is inserted in the 2nd intercostal space as an emergency measure. However, the breathing difficulty persists and a decision to insert an intercostal drain is taken. You would insert the chest drain into the triangle that lies _________.
  1. Posterior to the midaxillary line
  2. Anterior to the mid-axillary line
  3. Above the level of the nipple
  4. Below the level of the nipple
  5. Above and Medial to the pectoralis muscle
  6. Below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and chest X-ray is suggestive of tension pneumothorax. The safest site for insertion of a chest drain is the triangle of safety which lies:

  • Anterior to the mid-axillary line;
  • Above the level of the nipple;
  • Below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.

This will be present in the fifth intercostal space.

Pneumothorax refers to the collection of air between the lung and chest wall causing the lung to collapse. Tension pneumothorax develops when a "one-way valve" air leak occurs either from the lung or through the chest wall. Air is sucked into the thoracic cavity without any means of escape, completely collapsing and then compressing the affected lung.

Tension pneumothorax is characterized by chest pain, tachypnea, tachycardia, hypotension, tracheal deviation away from the side of injury, unilateral absence of breath sound, cyanosis, and neck vein distension.

Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, and treatment should never be delayed waiting for radiological confirmation.

Treatment consists of immediate decompression, initially by rapid insertion of a large-bore cannula on the affected side.

Due to the variable thickness of the chest wall, kinking of the catheter, and other technical or anatomic complications, needle decompression may not always be successful. In this case, finger thoracostomy is an alternative approach and is recommended as the next best step. 

Tube thoracostomy is mandatory after needle or finger decompression of the chest and is the definitive management.

The technique of drain insertion includes the following:

  • The area should be thoroughly sterilized before the procedure.
  • Adequate local anesthesia to include the pleura.
  • Sharp dissection should be done to cut only the skin.
  • Blunt dissection with artery forceps down through the muscle layers; which involve the serratus anterior and the intercostals.
  • An oblique tract is made so that the skin incision and the hole in the parietal pleura do not overlie each other and so that the drain is in a short tunnel, which reduces the chance of entraining air.
  • A drain for pneumothorax and haemothorax should aim towards the apex of the lung.
  • A drain for pleural effusion or empyema should be nearer the base.
  • The drain should pass over the upper edge of the rib to avoid injury to the neurovascular bundle that lies beneath the rib. 
  • A vertical mattress suture is inserted for later wound closure. This is important for pneumothorax management but not required if the drain is for empyema (provided there is the adherence of the pleura) because that tract should lie open.
  •  The drain should be connected to an underwater seal device which functions as a one-way valve.
  • Do not attach to a suction device at another end because it may worsen the air leak if the lung is fragile or might even cause a shift of mediastinum if the lung doesn't expand well
  • After completion, check the position of the drain by taking a chest radiograph.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy presenting with fever and pain over the right thigh. X-ray of the right femur revealed an onion skin appearance. Biopsy from the lesion is as shown below. This tumor is most likely to be found in the __________
questions.solution:
The most common site of presentation of Ewing's sarcoma is femoral diaphysis.

Ewing's sarcoma is a primary malignant bone tumor seen in children. It affects boys more than girls.

Ewing's sarcoma is most commonly seen in the diaphysis of long tubular bones like the femur and flat bones of the pelvis. It presents with pain and swelling in the affected site which is usually warm and tender. Systemic symptoms may be present. On X-ray, the characteristic onion peel appearance is seen due to periosteal reaction producing layers of reactive bone.

The tumor is soft and tan-white on gross appearance with multiple areas of hemorrhage and necrosis. On histopathology, sheets of small round cells with scant cytoplasm, which may appear clear because it is rich in glycogen. The presence of Homer-Wright rosettes, (tumor cells arranged in a circle about a central fibrillary space) is indicative of neuroectodermal differentiation.

Other options:

Option A: Clear cell chondrosarcoma is a tumor that commonly arises in the proximal femoral epiphysis. It is commonly seen in adulthood in the 3rd-5th decades.

Options B and C: Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant bone tumor seen in children and it is metaphyseal in origin. The most common presenting site is the distal femoral metaphysis. X-ray shows a typical sun-burst appearance and histopathology shows anaplastic cells with pleomorphism. Other tumors commonly seen in the metaphysis of long bones are osteochondroma, simple bone cysts, and aneurysmal bone cysts. These tumors are most commonly seen in persons < 20 years of age. However, this patient's X-ray and biopsy from the tumor are typical of Ewing's sarcoma.

questions.text: Which of the following manifestations do you expect to see in a patient with ferrochelatase deficiency?

choices.text: Increased urinary ALA and coproporphyrin III
Increased urinary ALA and porphyrobilinogen III (PBG)
Increased urinary ALA, PBG, and coproporphyrin III and fecal coproporphyrin III
Increased fecal and red cell protoporphyrin IX

questions.solution:
Increased fecal and red cell protoporphyrin IX is seen in ferrochelatase deficiency. This leads to Protoporphyria.

Other options:

Option A: Increased urinary ALA and coproporphyrin III are seen in ALA dehydratase deficiency.

Option B: Increased urinary ALA and porphyrobilinogen III (PBG) are seen in uroporphyrinogen I synthase deficiency causing acute intermittent porphyria. This enzyme is also called PBG deaminase or hydroxymethylbilane synthase.

Option C: Increased urinary ALA, PBG, and coproporphyrin III, and fecal coproporphyrin III is seen in coproporphyrinogen oxidase deficiency causing hereditary coproporphyria.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female comes for a routine gynecological examination. She has no significant past history. She is sexually active with her partner and uses condoms inconsistently. She has regular menstrual cycles and her last menstrual period was 6 days ago. Her external genitalia appears normal. On colposcopy, there are multiple small warty growths on the posterior vaginal wall which appear as patches of raised white epithelium on the application of acetic acid. Which of the following is the best recommendation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Local trichloroacetic acid+ fluorouracil application is the best recommendation for this patient with multiple small warty growths on the posterior wall of the vagina. In a sexually active female, these lesions are most likely to be condyloma acuminata.

The verrucous growths may appear discrete or coalesce to form large cauliflower-like growths. Human papillomaviruses (HPV) strains 6, 16, and 18 are implicated in causing condyloma acuminatum. On the application of acetic acid, these warts appear as raised projections of white epithelium giving a speckled appearance on colposcopy. 

Topical application of 25% trichloroacetic acid plus 5% fluorouracil causes sloughing off of small warts in 3-4 days. The treatment has to be repeated weekly as warts recur in 3-6 weeks' time. The sexual partner should be treated simultaneously and advised to use condoms to stop the spread of infection. Cesarian section is mandated in pregnant women with vulval or vaginal warts to avoid papilloma laryngitis in neonates.

Condyloma is associated with vaginal, vulval and cervical cancer in 20% of the cases. Lately, interferon local ointment or intralesional injections are in use. Interferon inhibits viral and cellular growth. 

Other options: 

Option B: Local podophyllin application is also useful in the treatment of small anogenital warts in condyloma acuminata. However, local application of podophyllin is contraindicated in vaginal and cervical lesions as it provokes a severe inflammatory reaction damaging the mucosa. It is also contraindicated in the first trimester of pregnancy as it can be absorbed into the circulation and is cytotoxic. 

Option C: Reassurance and observation is recommended in women with flat lesions especially during pregnancy as they tend to disappear in 6 months.

Option D: Laser ablation is recommended for larger lesions or small lesions not responsive to medical therapy.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is a myringotome. It is a sharp surgical knife used for paracentesis of the eardrum during myringotomy. 

Other options-

Option A- Lempert’s curette (scoop) is used for the removal of bony septa and granulations in mastoid surgery.

 

Option C- MacEwen’s curette and cell seeker used in mastoid surgery to explore the air cells with one end and to curette the intervening septa and granulations with the other.

Option D- Tilley Lichtwitz trocar and cannula are used for proof punctures (antral lavage). Puncture using the trocar is done in the inferior meatus because this site is easily accessible and safe.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male came to the physician with complaints of chronic back pain and easy fatigability. He has also been treated twice for urinary tract infections in the last 3 months. An x-ray of his skull is shown below. Which of the following laboratory parameters is consistent with this diagnosis?

choices.text: Hypercalcemia, high alkaline phosphatase and normal ESR
Hypercalcemia, high alkaline phosphatase, elevated ESR
Hypercalcemia, normal alkaline phosphatase, normal ESR
Hypercalcemia, normal alkaline phosphatase, elevated ESR

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the skull radiograph showing punched-out lesions suggest multiple myeloma. Hypercalcemia, normal alkaline phosphatase, and elevated ESR are the laboratory parameters consistent with a diagnosis of multiple myeloma.

Multiple myeloma is a malignant plasma cell dyscrasia with the proliferation of plasma cells derived from a single clone. Bone pain is the most common symptom of multiple myeloma. Tumor cells release osteoclast activating factors (OAFs), which increased osteoclast activity and accelerated bone destruction. Furthermore, there is suppression of osteoblast activity to form new bone. Lysis of the bone leads to hypercalcemia. Patients with multiple myeloma also have an increased susceptibility to infections because of diffuse hypogammaglobulinemia (decreased production and increased destruction) of normal antibodies. 

Other important features of multiple myeloma include: 

  • Renal failure
  • Normocytic and normochromic anemia
  • Hyperviscosity syndromes
  • Elevated ESR
  • Normal alkaline phosphatase due to suppression of osteoblast activity.
  • Serum protein electrophoresis shows the presence of monoclonal protein
  • Urinalysis shows free kappa and lambda light chains (Bence-Jones proteins)

Diagnostic Criteria for Multiple Myeloma include: 

Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥10% (or) biopsy-proven bony or extramedullary plasmacytoma

plus

Any one or more of the following myeloma-defining events:

  • Evidence of end-organ damage attributable to the underlying plasma cell proliferative disorder, specifically: (CRAB features)
    • Hypercalcemia: Serum calcium level >1 mg/dL higher than the upper limit of normal or >11 mg/dL
    • Renal insufficiency: Serum creatinine >2 mg/dL
    • Anemia: Hemoglobin level of >2 g/dL below the lowest limit of normal, or Hb <10 g/dL
    • Bone lesions: One or more osteolytic lesions on radiography, computed tomography (CT), or positron emission tomography (PET).
  • Any one or more of the following biomarkers of malignancy:
    • Clonal bone marrow plasma cells ≥ 60%
    • Serum involved / uninvolved free light-chain ratio of 100 or greater.
    • >1 focal lesion on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).

Related Pearl: Causes of lytic lesions in the skull

  • Eosinophilic granuloma (geographic lytic lesions in the vault of skull with beveled edges)
  • Multiple myeloma (punched out lytic lesion)
  • Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (permeative lesions)
  • Hyperparathyroidism (salt and pepper skull)
  • Metastasis
  • Lymphoma
  • Tuberculosis 
  • Osteomyelitis 
  • Radiation 

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Plasma Cell Neoplasms

  • Solitary plasmacytoma: Localized tumour of monoclonal plasma cells with no clinical features of plasma cell myeloma
  • Extramedullary(extraosseous) plasmacytoma: Localized plasma cell neoplasms that arise in tissues other than bone

questions.text: A 36-year-old obese woman, G3P2L2 at 38 weeks gestation is brought to the labor room with painless bleeding from the vagina following sexual intercourse with her husband. The patient has not had any antenatal care during this pregnancy except for her first dating scan which was normal. Her previous two pregnancies needed cesarian deliveries due to fetal distress. She is a chronic smoker. On examination, her vitals are stable. The uterus is soft, and non-tender. The fetal heart tracing shows a baseline heart rate of 150 beats/ min with accelerations, moderate variability, and no decelerations. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Transvaginal ultrasound is the next best step in the management of this patient presenting with painless vaginal bleeding at >20 weeks of gestation which is suspicious of placenta previa.

Placenta previa is defined as the implantation of the placenta partially or completely over the lower uterine segment, either over or adjacent to the internal os. Common risk factors for placenta previa include previous cesarian section or myomectomy, advanced maternal age (>35 years), smoking, multiple gestation, multiparity, and prior curettage.

In this patient, with advanced maternal age, previous two cesarian sections, and smoking history, the coital act could have led to the separation of the placenta leading to painless vaginal bleeding. Other causes of bleeding in placenta previa include physiological spontaneous separation, per vaginal examination, external cephalic version, and high rupture of membranes.

The next best step in this patient will be to confirm the diagnosis of placenta previa and localization through sonography. In transvaginal ultrasonography, the probe will be placed in the vagina without touching the endocervix. It is more accurate than transabdominal ultrasound (TAS) which also necessitates a full bladder for adequate visualization. Maternal obesity and posterior situation of the placenta also result in poor imaging in transabdominal ultrasonography.

Other options:

Option B: Fetal biophysical profile is done as a test of uteroplacental insufficiency in fetuses with a non-reactive non-stress test (NST). This fetus has a normal baseline heart rate (110-160 bpm) with accelerations, moderate variability, and no declarations. This is a reactive NST and does not need any further testing. This fetus is not in distress.

Option C: Fetal fibronectin is a glycoprotein that binds the fetal membranes to the decidua. The presence of fetal fibronectin in the cervical or vaginal discharge between 24-34 weeks of pregnancy is an indicator of preterm labor. It is normally found before 22 weeks and after 37 weeks of pregnancy and hence has no significance in this patient.

Option D: Vaginal delivery is contraindicated in placenta previa especially with a previous history of cesarian section. It may be considered if when the placental edge is clearly 2-3 cm away from the internal os as seen on USG. Further, this patient is hemodynamically stable and there is no evidence of fetal distress to necessitate immediate delivery. Definitive delivery through a Cesarian section after localizing the placenta is advisable.

Note: Per-Vaginal Examination should not be done in suspected placenta previa. In case of unavailability of USG or inconclusive ultrasonography it can be only done in the operation theatre with all the arrangements for Cesarian Section.

questions.text: A 23-year-old girl who is an alleged victim of rape is brought to the casualty. Samples are collected for the detection of semen. Which of the following tests is not useful in the detection of semen?
questions.solution:
Amongst the given tests, the Teichmann test is not used for semen detection. 

The Teichmann test or hemin crystal test is used to detect suspected bloodstains. It is performed by placing a small piece of suspected material on a glass slide. Then, 2-3 drops of glacial acetic acid and a small crystal of sodium chloride are added to the glass slide and covered with a coverslip. The slide is then heated.

If bloodstain is present, faint yellowish-red to brownish-black rhombic crystals of hemin or hematin chloride appear. When hydrogen peroxide is added, the hematin crystals produce bubbles of gas.

Other options:

Option B: P30 assay is a test to look for a glycoprotein produced by the prostate gland present in the semen (even of aspermic male), blood, and urine of a male. It may be found in the vagina up to 27 hours after intercourse. It is a reliable indicator of semen irrespective of acid phosphatase levels or the presence of sperm. 

Option C: Barberio test is used to detect seminal fluid and probably detect the presence of prostatic secretions. When a saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to the spermatic fluid, yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate are produced.

Option D: Acid phosphatase test detects the presence of high levels of acid phosphatase in seminal stains (low levels may be present in the vagina). Positive reactions are found till 36 hours, after which the levels fall and disappear within 72 hours.

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for seminal stains

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy comes to your clinic with his mother, with complaints of fever, headache, and cough for the past week. He had returned from a school trip about two weeks ago. On examination, his pulse was 100 beats per minute, BP was 100/70 mm of Hg, temperature was 99.8F. Auscultation revealed occasional rales and wheezes. Laboratory investigations revealed hemoglobin of 11g/dL and reticulocytosis and increased indirect bilirubin. Gram stain of the sputum was negative. Sputum cultures on blood agar were also negative. X-ray shows diffuse reticular nodular opacities and patchy consolidations. Which among the following antibiotics is the best among the given options for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is strongly suggestive of Mycoplasma pneumonia. The most appropriate antibiotic among the given options for the treatment of mycoplasma pneumonia is doxycycline. 

Mycoplasma pneumonia are small, pleomorphic, cell wall deficient bacteria, and are the smallest free-living organisms in nature that can be grown in a cell-free medium. They are covered by a soft membrane containing sterols. 

They are a common cause of community-acquired atypical pneumonia which is more commonly seen in the first two decades of life. It is transmitted through droplets and are hence more likely affects people who live in close quarters with each other such as schools, hostels, and military camps. 

Clinically, patients present with-

  • Non-specific symptoms- Such as fever, fatigue, cough, and malaise. While the patient may have only mild cough and fever, with clinical exam findings showing only scattered rales and wheezes, the X-ray will be strikingly worse with reticulonodular opacities and patchy consolidation. 
  • Extrapulmonary complications-
    • Hematological manifestations- Include immune hemolysis due to the formation of cold agglutinins. It is seen in more than half of the patients. Cold agglutinins are IgM antibodies against the I antigen present on RBCs. They are called cold agglutinins because they cause agglutination of RBCs at 4°C which is reversible at 37°C. Other hematological manifestations include aplastic anemia, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and hypercoagulopathy.
    • Other extrapulmonary manifestations include erythema multiforme major, and more rarely bullous myringitis, meningitis, meningoencephalitis, myocarditis, pericarditis, and arthritis.

Investigations include serological testing through enzyme-linked immunoassay (EIA) and polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Although not routinely used for clinical diagnosis, mycoplasma can be cultured in fluid or solid media that is enriched with serum and yeast extract, as they have a specific requirement of sterols for growth and membrane synthesis. Colonies tend to have a characteristic "fried-egg" appearance and may be best studied by staining using the Dienes method.

Treatment of mycoplasma includes tetracyclines, macrolides, or fluoroquinolones. They are completely resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics such as penicillins and cephalosporins because they lack a cell wall. 

Other options- Amoxicillin, cephalexin, and imipenem are beta-lactam antibiotics are hence not effective in the treatment of mycoplasma pneumonia.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old female presented with multiple joint pains and easy fatiguability. On examination, the following finding was seen. An X-ray was performed and is given below. Her lab findings are shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?

 

Lab Investigations

  • MCV - 80 fl (Normal: 87-96 fl)
  • ESR after 1 hour - 80mm
  • Serum Iron - 45 μg/dl (Normal - 50-150 μg/dl)
  • TIBC - 250 μg/dl (Normal -300-360 μg/dl)
  • Transferrin Saturation - 11 % (Normal:30-50%)
  • Serum Ferritin - 185 μg/L (Normal:50-200)
  • RA factor - strongly positive
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the image shows swan neck deformity with low MCV, low TIBC, and low transferrin saturation pointing towards the diagnosis of anemia of chronic disease secondary to Rheumatoid Arthritis. 

The chronic illnesses associated with  anemia of chronic disease can be grouped into three categories:

  1. Chronic microbial infections, such as osteomyelitis, bacterial endocarditis, and lung abscess
  2. Chronic immune disorders, such as rheumatoid arthritis and regional enteritis
  3. Neoplasms, such as carcinomas of the lung and breast and Hodgkin lymphoma

Interleukin-6 (IL-6), stimulates an increase in the hepatic production of hepcidin. Hepcidin inhibits ferroportin function in macrophages and reduces the transfer of iron from the storage pool to developing erythroid precursors in the bone marrow.

Erythropoietin levels are inappropriately low for the degree of anemia.

Other options:

Option A - Serum ferritin and TIBC can be used to distinguish iron deficiency anemia from anemia of chronic disease. Iron deficiency anemia will have low serum ferritin. Additionally, high TIBC and low transferrin saturation may be seen in iron deficiency anemia.

Options C & D- Sideroblastic anemia and thalassemia will have a normal TIBC with a normal to high transferrin saturation.

questions.text: A plain radiograph of a patient who was involved in a road traffic accident is as given below. During clinical examination his limb would be found to be:
questions.solution:
The plain radiograph of this patient shows anterior dislocation of the hip. On physical examination, the affected limb will be abducted and externally rotated. 

Other findings in anterior dislocation of the hip joint include a slightly flexed limb and a prominent anterior bulge in the pubic or groin region. According to the position assumed by the femoral head, anterior dislocation of the hip can further be classified as -

  • Type I - If the femoral head is felt anteriorly it is called as the superior/pubic type
  • Type II - If the femoral head is felt in the groin it is called as the inferior/obturator type

On an X-ray, the displaced femoral head will appear larger than the normal side. A lateral view X-ray will be confirmatory. 

The most common nerve injured in an anterior hip dislocation is the femoral nerve.

Treatment of anterior dislocation includes a closed reduction under sedation or general anesthesia. If closed reduction fails, an open procedure may be planned. 

The image below shows, a patient with an externally rotated, abducted, and slightly flexed left leg due to anterior dislocation of the hip:

 

Posterior dislocation of the hip is more common than anterior dislocation. It is caused due to a high energy impact to the knee, forcing the femoral head posteriorly.

On examination, the limb is adducted and internally rotated in a posterior dislocation of the hip. It also tends to be shortened and slightly flexed. On an X-ray, the displaced femoral head is higher and appears smaller than the normal side.

The most common nerve injured is the sciatic nerve as it lies behind the posterior wall of the acetabulum.

Treatment of posterior dislocation includes a closed reduction under sedation or general anesthesia. 

X-ray showing posterior dislocation of the hip:

Related Pearl: Anterior and posterior dislocation of the hip

  Anterior dislocation Posterior dislocation
Prevalence Less common Most common
Type of injury Deceleration injury/ Fall from height Dashboard injury
Attitude of the limb Flexion, abduction, external rotation (FABER) Flexion, adduction, internal rotation (FADIR)
Length of the limb Lengthened Shortened
Radiological findings
  • Femoral head may be seen inferior to the acetabulum
  • Femoral head appears larger than normal 
  • Lesser trochanter is prominent
  • Femoral head is displaced superiorly and laterally
  • Femoral head appears smaller than normal
  • Lesser trochanter is not visualised
Nerve injured  Femoral nerve  Sciatic nerve

questions.text:
A 46-year-old female came with complaints of a dry nagging cough and breathlessness on walking for a short distance. She is a chronic smoker and smokes 1 pack per day. On examination, there was dullness to percussion and reduced breath sounds on the right side. Chest X-ray showed moderate pleural effusion. Thoracocentesis was performed under ultrasound guidance, which relieved her symptoms. The lab investigations are given below. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis in this patient?

 Pleural fluid findings: 

  • Appearance: turbid
  • pH: 7.1
  • Protein: 3.2 g/dL
  • Lactate dehydrogenase: 1000 U/L (normal serum LDH - 50-150 U/L)
  • Pleural fluid protein/serum protein ratio : 0.64
  • Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH : 7.1
  • Glucose: 54 mg/dL
  • WBC count: 4000 cells/μL with > 50% lymphocytes
  • Adenosine deaminase: 30 U/L
  • AFB smear microscopy: negative
  • Gram staining and microscopy: no organisms, no pus cells
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings are suggestive of malignant pleural effusion.

In this patient, 

  • Pleural fluid protein/serum protein ratio : 0.64 (>0.5)
  • Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH : 7.1 (>0.6)
  • Pleural fluid LDH is > 2/3rd the upper limit of normal serum LDH (normal serum LDH - 50-150 U/L)

In this patient, according to Light's criteria, the pleural effusion is exudative.

Malignant pleural effusions secondary to metastatic disease are the second most common cause of exudative pleural effusions. In malignant pleural effusions, the dyspnea is out of proportion to the volume of effusion. Characteristics of malignant pleural effusion include:

  • Appearance may be cloudy or straw-colored or bloody
  • pH < 7.2
  • Glucose < 60 mg/dL
  • Cell counts - RBC count ranges from 100 to several hundred thousand, WBC count ranges from 1000 - 100,000 cells/μL with a predominance of lymphocytes
  • Cytology of pleural fluid is the gold standard of diagnosis of malignant pleural effusion. Abnormal cells with multiple nucleoli and figures of mitosis are diagnostic of malignant pleural effusion.

Management of malignant pleural effusion includes therapeutic thoracocentesis followed by insertion of a small indwelling catheter or tube thoracostomy with instillation of sclerosing agents.

Other options:

Option A: In parapneumonic pleural effusion too, the effusion is exudative with pH < 7.2 and glucose < 60 mg/dL. However, the WBC count is usually >10,000 cells/μL with a predominance of neutrophils. Appearance is generally cloudy.

Option C: Pleural effusion associated with congestive heart failure is transudative in nature.

Option D: Although tubercular pleural effusion is also exudative with a predominance of lymphocytes, adenosine deaminase levels < 40 U/L as in this patient rules out tubercular effusion.

Related Pearl: Types of pleural effusion

Transudative Pleural effusion

  • Congestive heart failure (most common)
  • Cirrhosis
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Myxedema 
  • Peritoneal dialysis
  • Urinothorax
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Constrictive pericarditis
  • Superior vena cava obstruction

Exudative Pleural effusion 

  • Infections: Tuberculosis, pneumonia, intraabdominal abscess (like- liver abscess)
  • Malignancy: Pleural mesothelioma, metastasis, lymphoma
  • Connective tissue diseases: SLE, rheumatoid arthritis
  • Drugs: Amiodarone, bromocriptine, dantrolene, dasatinib, methysergide, nitrofurantoin
  • Others:
    • Pancreatitis
    • Asbestosis
    • Pulmonary embolism
    • Hemothorax
    • Chylothorax
    • Meigs' syndrome 
    • Dressler syndrome (post-myocardial infarction or cardiac surgery)
    • Yellow nail syndrome
